content: I am receiving more and more spam sent to me via @rust-lang.org addresses which I dare not pass to my classifiers because that risks them deciding that @rust-lang.org is a spam provider. Is there anything infra can do to capture/reduce these, and if so, is there an address I should forward uncaught things to?

Hm, I'm a bit wary of you directly forwarding (in case you get marked as a spammer). I'm not sure how much we can do right now, but there's been some thinking about the communications infrastructure in general, and I suspect that this particular problem is potentially solvable with some investment. Maybe you can screenshot a couple and send an email to infra@? That would help at least understand what they look like :)

I am also getting a lot of spam. It has a To address of team@. Most of it is that something is "ready for delivery" and you need to give your address to deliver it to. Or they have a "new product". On several occasions the DKIM(?) was incorrect, so I think it gets directly sent to my own email rather than through a forward from team@.
I only have one to hand, but I'll send a png of it, and of its headers.
Thanks. I'm not sure how much we can do, but it's definitely a useful data point, thank you for raising it.

If there were a way to get mailgun to classify the mails, then I could add a custom rule to take that into account directly. It's hard for systems downstream of something like mailgun to sensibly apply learning to such mails without risking identifying mailgun or rust-lang.org as spammers
google already classifies all of that mail as spam fwiw, there are robots, massage chairs and whatnot in there.
Yeah, my personal threshold is higher than google's because I have a number of less-good family members who forward things to me and are sad when my mail system learns them as spammers
But as a corollary, I often have to go spam-bin diving on my gmail to retrieve non-spams, so it's swings and roundabouts
